ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hypothalamic/Thalamic Tumor (Glioblastoma Multiforme)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by surgery and pathology; explains the central auditory deficits (ABR, MLR, behavioral) and progressive neurological symptoms.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Multiple Sclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered for several years due to motor instability and weakness, but ruled out by the discovery of the tumor.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Presbycusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Likely accounts for the bilateral symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss but does not explain the central processing deficits or neurological decline.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing sensitivity given complaints of difficulty hearing conversations.
Assess integrity of the reflex arc to screen for retrocochlear pathology.
Evaluate neural integrity of the auditory brainstem pathways.
Assess central auditory processing skills including dichotic listening and temporal processing.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient demonstrates a moderate-to-severe bilateral symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss with excellent speech recognition, likely presbycusic. Behavioral central tests show significant left-sided deficits (dichotic digits, competing sentences) and bilateral temporal processing issues.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Moderate to severe bilaterally symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss, sloping from mild in low frequencies to severe in high frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent speech recognition scores bilaterally (RE 92%, LE 96%).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels (reduced sensation levels at mid and high frequencies) bilaterally for 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Behavioral Central Auditory Tests
tests.result_summary: Left ear deficit on dichotic digits (~75%), competing sentences (65%), and compressed speech (~45%). Bilaterally suppressed filtered speech scores (~20%). Frequency Patterns (FP) normal bilaterally.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Electrophysiological testing reveals significant central pathology consistent with a lesion affecting the upper brainstem and thalamus. ABR shows absent waves IV-V on the left, and MLR is absent or poor on the left.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Waves I, III, V present (latencies: I=1.7ms, III=3.7ms, V=5.9ms). Left ear: Normal waves I and II; Wave III delayed; Absence of IV-V complex.

tests.name: Auditory Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.result_summary: Noisy/poor responses. T3 (left temporal) showed no repeatable response. T4 (right temporal) showed response to right ear stimulation only.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Radiologic and surgical findings confirmed the presence of a tumor.

tests.name: Radiologic and Surgical Findings
tests.result_summary: CT scans were difficult to read. Surgery revealed a tumor in the hypothalamus behind the optic chiasm (approx 1.5 cm), affecting the inferior thalamus. Pathology: Glioblastoma multiforme.

proposed_items: Communication strategies training for central auditory deficits
counseling_actions: Explain that peripheral hearing loss is likely age-related and not the primary cause of localization difficulties
Discuss abnormal brainstem and cortical responses indicating neural pathway disruption
Counsel on strategies to manage localization and speech-in-noise difficulties (e.g., visual cues, reducing background noise)

red_flags_present: Progressive neurological symptoms (left arm/leg weakness, confusion, memory loss)
Fullness sensation in the left ear
Abnormal ABR and MLR findings with symmetrical audiogram

escalation.rationale_short: Suspected retrocochlear lesion (tumor) requiring imaging and potential surgical intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Referral for neuroimaging (CT/MRI) and neurosurgical management.

expected_outcome: Surgery revealed a tumor in the hypothalamus behind the optic chiasm with a diameter of approximately 1.5 cm, affecting the inferior thalamus.
The lesion extended on the left posteriorly and inferiorly towards the brainstem.
Pathology reported the tumor to be a glioblastoma multiforme.
